abstract.text: Seamlessly schedule updates to your user interface, even while it’s inactive.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: When you schedule periodic updates to your user interface with
updates continue to run even when your app is in the
or
state,
making this an ideal choice for keeping a watchOS app up-to-date while in the Always
On state. Additionally, you can use a
to drive other changes — such as animation — when your app is running in the foreground.
Specify the part of your user interface that receives periodic updates using a

code: // Use a timeline to recalculate the value every minute.
// Display the current amount of caffeine in the user's body.

inlineContent.text: The
structure
takes a schedule that determines when the system makes updates. It also takes a
that defines the updatable content. The system then calls the view builder, passing
the context for each update.
The
instance
contains both the time and the current
for the updates. When creating the updatable content for the
use the time from the context, not the current system time. When in Always On, the
system may request views up to 5 minutes in the future.
The cadence also indicates the current maximum rate for updates that the
receives:
Receives high-frequency updates that are suitable for driving animation.
Receives up to one update per second.
Receives up to one update per minute.
The cadence can change from update to update. Always check the current value and
hide information that isn’t relevant. For example, a timer app may show the time
remaining in minutes, seconds, and hundredths of a second when it receives updates
at the
frequency. It can also play animation at that frequency.
When the updates drop to the
frequency, the app hides the hundredths of seconds and swaps the animation for a
static image. The countdown only shows minutes and seconds.
If the frequency drops to
the app also hides the seconds and only shows the time remaining to the nearest minute.
When you create a
you must specify the update schedule, which is an instance that adopts the
protocol. While you can create your own custom schedules, SwiftUI provides schedules
for many common use cases.
The system attempts to trigger updates based on the schedule, but it can delay or
defer an update based on the system’s current state. Additionally, if the schedule
is more frequent than the current cadence, the system throttles the updates to the
cadence.
Common schedules include:
A schedule to update the
every minute. These updates align with the system clock. For example, if the schedule starts at 1:00 pm, you’d get updates at 1:01, 1:02, 1:03, and so on.
A schedule to update your interface at a regular, repeating interval. When you create this schedule, you specify the starting time and the interval between updates.
A schedule to create a

instance with high-frequency updates for animated content. When you create the schedule, you can set both the minimum interval and a Boolean value that indicates whether the animation is currently paused. If you don’t set a minimum interval, the system picks an appropriate update interval. Additionally, it only updates the view when the paused parameter is
A schedule to specify a list of update times. For example, an app that plays audiobooks might schedule updates for the beginning of each chapter. When you create an explicit timeline, you pass a
, such as an
of
instances. The system updates the
at the time specified by each date in the sequence.
You can use timeline views to update your watchOS app while it’s in the Always On
state; however, you must be able to specify the view’s contents given a
instance for a time in the future. To improve performance, the system may ask for
views up to 5 minutes in the future. For example, an egg timer could use a
to display the time remaining during Always On because it can calculate the amount
of time remaining given any arbitrary time in the future.
When your app is active and in the foreground, the timeline schedule runs in the
mode, and your
can receive updates at the
cadence. When your app transitions into Always On, the timeline schedule also transitions
into the
mode, the cadence generally drops, and the system may batch-load future updates.
In the Always On state, apps running a background session may not need to
use a
to update
their user interface. Any changes the app makes while running in the background continue
to update its interface; however, to preserve battery life, the system only refreshes
the user interface about once per second. For more information, see
While the actual cadence can vary depending on the requested schedule and the current
state of the system, apps generally receive an update frequency based on whether
they have background runtime or are inactive, frontmost apps.
Apps with background runtime receive updates at the
frequency. This would include apps with an active background session (like workout
or background audio apps) or apps executing a background refresh task.
Inactive apps receive updates as long as they remain in the frontmost state, generally
at the
frequency. However, if you request a short burst of updates at the
frequency, the system provides that cadence if possible.
For example, an egg timer could use an
to set up per-minute updates for most of the countdown, and switch to per-second
updates for the last minute. If conditions permit, the system provides
updates for the last minute.

abstract.text: Use App Intents to register actions for your app.

abstract.text: An ordered, random-access collection.
A type that provides sequential, iterated access to its elements.
A pausable schedule of dates updating at a frequency no more quickly than the provided interval.
A schedule for updating a timeline view at the start of every minute.
A schedule for updating a timeline view at explicit points in time.
A schedule for updating a timeline view at regular intervals.
The scene isn’t currently visible in the UI.
The scene is in the foreground but should pause its work.
A type that provides a sequence of dates for use as a schedule.
A mode that produces schedule updates at a reduced rate.
A mode that produces schedule updates at the schedule’s natural cadence.
A view that updates according to a schedule that you provide.
Information passed to a timeline view’s content callback.
A rate at which timeline views can receive updates.
Updates the view continuously.
Updates the view approximately once per minute.
Updates the view approximately once per second.
A custom parameter attribute that constructs views from closures.
A specific point in time, independent of any calendar or time zone.
A false value.
